titleStmt.title: Ulysses. An electronic version of the critical and synoptic edition.

publicationStmt.p: This electronic edition was created as part of a Diplomarbeit for theTechnische Universität München. Note that the text and the edition are copyrighted and may not be distributed freely. The copyright notices of the printed edition still apply where applicable:
Draft texts, revisional material, and reading text of Ulysses ©1984, The Trustees of the Estate of James Joyce
Presentation of Genetic Synopsis, Notes and Afterword ©1984, Hans Walter Gabler
The compiler of the electronic version, from his side, agrees to all non-commercial use of his work.

notesStmt.note: This electronic edition was first automatically converted from the TUSTEP files used for preparation of the printed edition; necessary corrections and additional tagging were done by hand afterwards.

The electronic edition comprises the continuous manuscript text as on the left hand pages of the printed edition (this also implies the reading text, as on the right hand pages), the emendatory footnotes, the historical collation and the textual notes in the Appendix. The date information from table 1 on page 1913 is also incorporated, so are some data from the bibliography relevant to the historical collation. The preface, afterword, and the additional information in the bibliography and table 1 and 2 in the appendix are not included.

projectDesc.p: This electronic edition was prepared as part of a computer science Diplomarbeit for theTechnische Universität München. It is an attempt to remodel the information structure of the printed Gabler edition of Ulysses explicitly in SGML, as closely as possible to the TEI P3 standard.

With the time and resources given, the bulk of the SGML text files had to be generated automatically from the electronic documents used in the preparation of the printed edition. This hopefully gives a very correct text, but in many places gives crude and/or bad tagging.

The tagging applied shall serve two main purposes: To generate a TEI-compatible version of some particular level of the text, notably the reading text as established by the Gabler edition, and to create an online critical edition that allows more intuitive access to the information structures available in the Gabler edition.

quotation.p: Quotations are not tagged explicitly. Direct speech in the main text is marked exclusively with em dashes at the beginning of a new paragraph. What graphically looks like left and right single quotes in the main text are apostrophes and left single quotes used in contracted Irish names as M‘Coy and in similar forms of transcription (e.g. from Hebrew). These are coded as entity references to the standard ISO entities apos and lsquo. Quotations in the notes use single or double quotes.

hyphenation.p: End-of-line hyphenation and soft hyphens introduced for typographic reasons in the computer files for the printed edition is discarded or represented by soft hyphen entities (shy). Explicit hyphens in the text can be considered as hard hyphens in compound words. Hyphenation information related to Joyce's manuscripts that is provided explicitly in the printed edition is marked with word break tags (wbreak).

segmentation.p: The main text is separated in three divisions, representing the three parts of the book. Each part is subdivided into episodes, eighteen altogether. The episodes 7 (Aeolus), 10 (Wandering Rocks) and 17 (Ithaca) are again subdivided into their obvious elements.

stdVals.p: Where dates are given as attribute values, they are either of the form 1904 to denote a whole year, or of the form 1904-06-16 to denote a particular day (the sixteenth of June 1904 in this case). There are date and daterange elements without content where the date ist to be derived from the attributes.

refsDecl.p: Two canonical reference systems are coded into the main text: There are the page and line-per-page numbers of the left-hand pages (the synoptic pages) of the printed edition, which are coded with pb and lb milestones with the ed attribute set to syn (forsynoptic). And there are the lines-per-chapter numbers serving as a standard reference to the reading text of the Gabler edition, which are coded with lb tags with attribute ed set to gab (forGabler). To complete these references, one needs the chapter number given in the n attribute of the episode level div elements.
It may be unfortunate, but there are also lb tags in the notes that are not part of a reference system; they indicate a relevant line break in the source manuscript instead.

langUsage.language: The main language of the text is English, although a lot of the words are not Standard English but new coinages that often also mimic other languages. In the current version of the SGML transcription, no distinction of languages is made — all italics are just tagged as highlighted.

revisionDesc.change: SGML version frozen from the last automatic conversion. Incomplete and faulty in details.
Pushed and pulled through the needle's eye: it parses. Corrected some obvious conversion blunders, but not too systematically.

I have remodelled the file structure for the appendix slightly and added the layout specs for exceptional cases. I did a lot of manual editing at critical spots and have rerun the conversion for systematic blunders. The whole thing is a lot better now, but still needs testing and improvement. The tag set documentation is not completed.
